poem:
The Death of Bunny Munro  

Beneath Brighton's grey mist,  
Bunny traipses—a salesman of desire,  
hollowed by the echo of love gone.  
In dim lights, he dances grotesque,  
chasing shadows of embrace.  
A tale spun in scandal's thread,  
footprints lingering on a pebble beach,  
as the sea swallows whispers—  
his mourning, the world's refrain.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "TV tonight: Matt Smith is grotesque in Nick Cave’s scandalous drama The Death of Bunny Munro 9pm, Sky AtlanticMatt Smith is at his most grotesque in an unsettling drama based on Nick Cave’s scandalous novel of the same name (Cave also executive produces). It’s set in Brighton in 2003, with Smith playing Bunny Munro – a hedonistic sex-addict salesman who manages to charm many around him while enraging others. After the death of his wife,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
